thread.title: There’s another Indy taco fest, and this one’s authentic
thread.title_full: There’s another Indy taco fest, and this one’s authentic

author: liz.biro@indystar.com
title: There’s another Indy taco fest, and this one’s authentic
text:
There’s another Indy taco fest, and this one’s authentic Liz Biro , liz.biro@indystar.com Published 3:14 p.m.   5 hours ago CLOSE Share IndyStar food reporter Liz Biro visits the Mexican restaurant in Irvington. Liz Biro / IndyStar Mexican and Central American cooks run food trucks coming to the festival, so expect to taste tacos true to form Buy Photo These authentic carne asada tacos with were served at the the 2015 Familia Fest at Military Park. Sample more authentic tacos at Indy Taco Fest 2 to 9 p.m. Feb. 12 at Indiana Discount Mall in Indianapolis. Another taco fest is coming this summer to Pan American Pavilion in Downtown Indy. (Photo: Jenna Watson/IndyStar) Buy Photo 216 CONNECT 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
This week, you heard about a taco festival coming this summer to Downtown Indianapolis’ Pan American Pavilion. But another taco festival happens this weekend, and the tacos will be some of the most authentic you’ve ever eaten. 
What’s even better is that this latest taco festival will happen every month. 
The Feb. 12 Indy Taco Fest features eight to 10 food trucks, maybe more, serving tacos 2 to 9 p.m. at Indiana Discount Mall, 3585 Commercial Dr., in the International Marketplace neighborhood. 
Mexican and Central American cooks run trucks coming to the festival, so expect tacos true to form, said Paulino Alancho, events coordinator at Indy’s Vida Latina Magazine, which is co-hosting the event with Indiana Discount Mall. However, all food trucks serving tacos are welcome to participate. Call the mall office at 317-291-6502. 
Trucks on the roster so far include El Taco Loco, 2 burros, Dos Hermanos and a truck operated by Broad Ripple’s Biscuits restaurant (home of delectable carnitas that come with even more delectable pork skins), said Indiana Discount Mall office manager Israel Ortiz. Tacos aren’t the only thing on the menu. Trucks will serve a range of Latin American food. A photo posted by Liz Biro (@lizbiro) on Mar 9, 2016 at 9:22am PST 
At this weekend’s festival, you may also get margaritas, beer and a michelada, that beer cocktail sometimes called a “Mexican bloody mary.” The drink is made with beer, spices, lime and sauces. Some people use the tomato juice brand Clamato, but recipes vary from maker to maker. 
The festival, featuring a karaoke contest and dancing, is free to attend. Trucks will sell food directly to attendees. 
Organizers plan to stage a taco festival at the mall the third Sunday of every month, with each festival larger than last, Ortiz said. The idea is to share Latin American culture. 
“We try to promote unity. That’s the main idea of the taco festival,” Alancho said. “We want to get people together. Right now, there is a lot of fear in a lot of Latino communities. We want to provide a good, positive experience to get together.” 
A date has not been set for this summer's Downtown taco festival, but organizers of that event say it will probably happen in June. It's billed Tacos, Tequila and Margaritas Festival . 
Follow IndyStar food writer Liz Biro on Twitter: @lizbiro , Instagram: @lizbiro , Facebook and Pinterest . Call her at (317) 444-6264.
